This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Okay. Anyway, my name is Jason Scott. I run a place called textfiles.com, which is a website dedicated to, well its official mantra is we are the official place for bulletin board system texts of the 1980s.
Now, to make that work, if you used one of these, this was that era.

Basically what happened was, by its very nature, bulletin board systems had a lot of text files on them where people traded and the nature of the distribution channel was that you had single line phones and so basically it was very slow as compared to today.
So as a result, there were a lot of files that people kept but when the internet came along, the real push was for things that were aimed already up on FTP sites and internet.
So we have a real huge amount of text files that were created after say 1993, 1994 and not as many that were created from the 80s or even the 70s or the 60s.
So I was really concerned about that stuff going away and so I started taking my text file collection and I started taking text file collections of others and putting it together.
When I spoke last year, I had 9,000 text files with a bunch in the inbox.
Now I'm at 23,000 text files.
I'm not stopping and luckily most of the important ones, the ones that people usually think of are up on there.

Now what I'm talking about today is less about what the history was at that time and more about what it's like to run textfiles.com because I'm a solid sitting duck target for some very interesting groups of people and I figured that would be somewhat amusing.
What I'm doing is I'm actually technically a file archive.
I like to think of myself as a librarian.

I'm really not writing my own stuff except for to comment on stuff that's already written or I am putting together things by my own weird little classification system so people can download it quicker.
One thing I do find is that people have some very distinct ideas about what they want so I started putting archives of the sections together and I can see very quickly what people like.
The number one search on my engine is how to make LSD.
Every month, every month, 30 to 40 hits, how to make LSD.

Now one of the other things that's very interesting about my site is because I have 23,000 text files currently numbering around 500 or 600 megabytes of text, you get some pretty wacky search matches.
So my referral log can really clear your sinuses.

Now I would have preferred just being some quiet little thing off in the corner doing my little work, bringing it up, making sure people knew about it and sending it out there but life isn't like that on the internet anymore.
A lot of people come up on panels and speeches like this and they spend a lot of time going, I think freedom is very good and I'd like you all to agree with me.
And they spend a lot of time telling you basically that, that freedom is good.

I believe freedom is very good too but what I'm worried about are the people who don't recognize that they're against some things which freedom would actually cover because they have their own agenda.
One of the little themes that has always gone through bulletin board systems and it's effective now are the twin towers of bombs and drugs.
As long as bulletin board systems have been in existence and certainly today, boys, adolescents and older, like to blow shit up and like to smoke shit up.
I like to call that the Beavis and Butthead Syndrome.
Yes, exactly.
Now I do understand that. I do have some dark portions of my past.
When I was 13 years old I was busted in my school for selling ASCII pornography.
I'm sure you all have similar skeletons in your closet.
Basically we were printing out a file on my system called Angela.org and we're just printing it and selling it for 50 cents a pop to the highest bidder who ever wanted it.
This was quickly discovered by our crack security force at my school and I was hauled into the principal's office.
That's where I first really came up against the theory figure where I really didn't think I was wrong on an issue of expression.
Basically he was like, do you know how wrong it is in what you're doing?
I said, no.
He said, don't you think this is wrong?
I said, being an ass, I see a bunch of letters and numbers, sir. I don't know what you see.
I lost it but I used to have, when I got detention, I had a little slip that said selling of erotic art images in school or something or whatever the dumb little trumped up charge was.
There was actually another one I sure learned two years later.
I'm in my class and there's a call.
Hello, Jason, please come to the main office.
So I come to the main office.
There's my mom.
There's the principal.
There's a man in a suit.
This isn't good.
Man in a suit comes up and says, I'm from the FBI.
This is definitely not good.
We found out you were selling nitroglycerin plans to kids.
Fifty cents a pop.
Turns out one of the kids, dad was a cop.
Dad wasn't pleased.
Dad found it in his kid's notebook.
Called the FBI.
FBI said, where did you get this?
I said, some board in Illinois.
I don't know.
They said, okay, don't do that again.
Which was surprising.
I figured they could really kick my ass, but they didn't.
And why was I doing that?
When you see kids doing stupid stuff like this, you go, why are they doing that?
I felt a sense of power.
Here I was.
I had the magic stuff, the magic recipe that would blow shit up.
It was my power.
I didn't have a car.
I didn't have a girlfriend.
I had my way.

I'm watching you.
